ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned to draw, use drawing tools and processes, and the varying mediums.
Developed a drawing practice, became more confident and excited to draw. Learned a variety of techniques and mediums.

This class was really great for establishing the fundamentals of drawingline, value, perspective, etc. I think I improved a lot in terms of my basic skills and also applying what I learned to interesting concepts.
I learned basic art techniques and schools of thought, utilizing a variety of different materials and mediums.
I learned how to create dimension, draw from life, and use a variety a different drawing materials on a page.
Learned the basics of drawing: value, perspective, figure, self portrait, etc. I got A LOT better at drawing from this class.
I developed basic understanding on how to draw, including pushing values, understanding linear perspectives, etc.
Line, form, value, perspective, figure drawing; lots of practice and learning by doing
I learned how to draw with graphite and charcoal.

This was a great class! I learned a lot about drawing techniques, how to look at an object, how to observe and draw shadows and different textures, and how to draw figures. I experimented with a lot of different techniques and learned to draw in charcoal and ink.

This class teaches you not only how to draw realistically but also how to draw out concepts and ideas that do not yet have a visual form and being comfortable with exploring its visual form. This class also exposes you to many kinds of art-making materials and encourages you to explore them.
I learned the introductory drawing skills and basic artistic principles.
I learned VERY IMPORTANT TECHNIQUES!!! I actually improved like crazy
I learned how to take risks and embrace my mistakes, as well as how to spend time on things that I enjoy/

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was very well structured and professor Sheehan had a clear plan for our drawing development.

I love that Prof. Sheehan pushed me to explore what's exciting for me and provided me with feedback and advice on what to explore. I really liked that we got to explore a lot of mediums and a variety of drawing processes, including screen printing. Learning some more techniques of drawing could be cool.

I think the strength of the class is it is accessible for artists of all levels. The flip side of this is that for someone with a strong art background it doesn't feel as a challenging/doesn't push you that hard. But I think there's a lot of value to reviewing the fundamentals with a class with diverse art backgrounds.
More field trips

This course has many strengths: we received great feedback, had the space to explore what we wanted to do, but also practiced different types of drawing techniques. I dont think this course has weaknesses.
Only strengths! Take this class!
A strength was the wonderful instructor! Carly was great and taught wonderfully. A weakness may be the fast pace of the class.

Tons of practice in the class and through at-home assignments. Strengths are a lot of practicing through doing. Good resources in the class. Our prof bought us a lot of materials and also had live figures come in for figure drawing. Prof Sheehan was a great teacher and definitely one of the strengths of the class. She emphasizes creativity, exploration, and "not being precious" with materials. I think it was really valuable to learn that it's easy to want to think you "messed up" and want to start over, but part of the process is just continuing to work at the art and keep adding, even if you're uncomfortable.
The final project was very individual, so you get out what you put in.

With this course, you get to develop a daily drawing practice and also work in the studio. It's really cool seeing other students' works and progress, as well as your own. The assignments and exercises are diverse and give you a great opportunity to explore a different range of techniques, styles, subjects, and approaches to your art. The class is very accessible to both art majors and non-art majors.

This course gives you the space to explore many ideas and ways of art-making but also has some structure. You are given an assignment or setup to draw in class, but you can choose to draw it in whatever method you feel comfortable trying out, and students are encouraged to think more about the process than train to become hyperrealistic human cameras.

Weaknesses: I don't think the course was designed well to give students feedback on their work. Although the class is intended to facilitate self-exploration, there were times where feedback was lacking.
It would be great if there hadn't been a course fee.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I absolutely would. No matter the skill coming in, you will grow and develop you abilities, as well as have a fun portfolio at the end.
Yes; this course is very well taught and is a great introduction to drawing!
Yes! It's a great course if you'd like to start drawing more and learn about what a large variety of drawing techniques and styles exist. Also Prof. Sheehan is so kind and helpful, she's the best.
Yes, its a great class for art and non-art majors. Definitely a good first step into art for those who arent sure if they want to add an art major.

I would definitely recommend! For perspective art majors, it's a prereq and also very fun and you will review the basics in a helpful way. For others, it is definitely worth it. I think it's super valuable to branch out and you'll find it fulfilling. It's not too much work, but even more importantly you build your own body of creative work and the time you spend in class feels like a refreshing break from academics.
Yes! This course was a constructive, valuable, and fun experience. I learned and improved greatly as an artist.
Yes! If you can't get into this class, stay on the waitlist!
Yes, this class was so fun and also so instructive! I learned how to improve my art and also had a great time while doing it.

Yes, definitely. That being said, this is NOT a gut! It takes a lot of work! If you think it'll be an easy 5th class on top of an already difficult, high workload schedule, you'll be in for a surprise. This class has a lot of homework, more than many problem set classes or essay classes. And you're expected to draw a lot outside of class. Definitely think of this class as a time-intensive class but one that's worthwhile if you put the time in. It's very much a "get what you put in" kind of class.
Yes

Yes! This is a great class that allows you to explore your own drawing style and learn new techniques. For the most part, you get what you put in, and you can really improve artistically if you dedicate yourself to the class and put in the effort. I recommend it to anyone who wants to draw more and improve!
Yes
I'd recommend this course to another student looking to learn how to draw or who likes to draw. It is a fair bit of work, so if you're not interested in the course material it can feel strenuous.
Yeah, you do have to do a lot of work (weekly assignments) but you learn so so much
Absolutely. I thoroughly enjoyed this class and I never once wanted to skip.
